This would disallow adding a certificate by admin in the subcloud since it would be deleted by dcorch.  Please review whether this should be deleting these 'extra' certificates (unless they're expired).

> This would disallow adding a certificate by admin in the subcloud
 > since it would be deleted by dcorch.  Please review whether this
 > should be deleting these 'extra' certificates (unless they're
 > expired).

dcorch only tracks resources that exist in System Controller. It doesn't delete resources added by admin in subclouds. In another word, it wouldn't audit resources exist only in subclouds as extra. This is by the audit algorithm.

controllers/memcached_controller.go.message:
same suggestions as the other one, however, i think something we should do here is be aware that size is dynamically calculated.  if you create a memcache of 128MB, it will result in a deployment of replica = 2 with 64M on each one.  I think what we should do for the memory limits is have this number be equal to the variable `size` (which is the size of the replica) * 1.10 (10% for error)

so ideally

size * 1.10 * units.MiB
and this one should be size * units.MiB

if size is 64, I think this will result in

64MiB + 6528KiB (aka 6.3MiB)

That seems reasonable, we can tweak this later if we feel it's not right.

Well, in fact, I tried to make 1.1 for the size.
So 1*size + 0.1*size = 1M * size + 0.1M * size = units.MiB * size + 102.4 * units.KiB * size

So I tried size * units.MiB + 102* size * units.KiB.
:)
let's drop the initial delay on memcache too, it's pretty fast to start.

neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/.message: Can You maybe add new UT or change existing one which is in neutron/tests/unit/plugins/ml2/drivers/openvswitch/agent/test_ovs_neutron_agent.py (test test_process_ports_events_port_removed_and_added) to cover such case?

Thank you very much for catching this bug. I can confirm this is happening.

This way of updating the event dictionary is not very efficient.

I suggest the following one, to avoid re-creating in every loop the 'removed' and 'added' keys:

    ports_re_added = added_ports & removed_ports
    ports_re_added = [p for p in ports_re_added if
                      ovs_lib.BaseOVS().port_exists(p)]
    events['re_added'] = [e for e in events['removed']
                          if e['name'] in ports_re_added]
    events['removed'] = [e for e in events['removed'] if e['name']
                         not in ports_re_added]
    ports_removed = [p['name'] for p in events['removed']]
    events['added'] = [e for e in events['added'] if e['name'] not in
                       ports_removed]

playbookconfig/src/playbooks/roles/boots.message: Do we need to support backup/restore for these certificates? If so, changes will be required to restore_prep_tasks.yml.

Thanks Andy. What will happen if two users attempt to  install a new certificate at the same time? Or if one user attempts an install and another does a delete at the same time? How big are these files? If it makes more sense to have them in the database, I don't think size is a big deal.

> Do we need to support backup/restore for these certificates? If so,
 > changes will be required to restore_prep_tasks.yml.

There is implication wrt B&R. I will update the certificate installation API so that we don't need to backup and restore the certs files in config_permdir/ssl_ca.

I'll update this review once the changes in the API are ready.

Please explain why it is not necessary to back thes up and restore them. Also, if these files are not required for a backup/restore, I assume the files aren't required at runtime either, so why are we creating a new permdir for them at all?

> Please explain why it is not necessary to back thes up and restore
 > them. Also, if these files are not required for a backup/restore, I
 > assume the files aren't required at runtime either, so why are we
 > creating a new permdir for them at all?

The way the certificate install (for multiple CA certs) works is that sysinv stores each of the CA certs in that directory as a single file, with its signature as its file name. sysinv then cats these files together into ca-cert.pem and passes it to the Linux "update-ca-trust" command in puppet config runtime class to update system trusted CA certificate list. This Linux command takes ca-cert.pem as input. 

I didn't change the existing mechanism to update system trusted CA list in puppet config runtime class (ie update-ca-trust with ca-cert.pem). I just enhanced sysinv to store each of the CA certs as a file in that directory. This helps the implementation of certificate uninstall. So the uninstall just delete that particular cert file, re-cat these files in that directory and call puppet config runtime class again.

So the new dir and cert files in it basically are where sysinv stores and track CA certs in the system. I thought about storing them in sysinv DB, but CA cert can be fairly large.

At the end, ca-cert.pem contains all the CA certs user ever installed. B&R backup it up, and restore by "system certificate-install -m ssl_ca tempdir/ca-cert.pem". This will update the system trusted CA list, as well as generate these cert files for sysinv.

The way of validating if a Load Balancer is healthy is the same as the part validation method for Round Robin [1].
That is why the _wait_for_lb_functional() started failing, because it assumes the Load_Balancer is configured with Round Robin algorithm, by using the HTTP session.

I can update the patch and leave this code untouched, except removing the session and sending each requests independently.


https://github.com/openstack/octavia-tempest-plugin/blob/29d179016a2c2299d1c20c4ae69cb719e0f34b4f/octavia_tempest_plugin/tests/test_base.py#L1057

For SOURCE_IP_PORT mechanism we can define two validations:

1) Do not use a session and validate both members answered. That is how it works in L1054.

2) Use a session and validate that only *one* member
answered.


That is why I added this before. The typical session-persistence use-case is when HTTP(s) protocol is used, but it can be also TCP or UDP. This checks started to fail when tests for UDP protocol has been merged.

I think that for now with current UDP server <> client implementation we don't have a possibility to reuse the same client connection, right? That is why I added this additional check.

This is not good. It's "secretly" hiding that it is swapping out the protocol.
We need to simply fix this method to handle protocol TCP correctly or rename this to be an HTTP/HTTPS specific method.

Prior UDP patch it worked the same. If the TCP protocol was specified in octavia tempest plugin configuration [1] the HTTP request was send. That worked for OVN Octavia provider - as it supports only Load Balancers with TCP or UDP. The Load Balancer was created using protocol configured in tempest plugin config and then the HTTP request was send to it

InvalidSchema: No connection adapters were found for 'tcp://IP:port'

I was experimenting with this but the connection entry in the database does not go away when the connection is killed or even the service (q-svc) is stopped. If we are going to rely on the Connection table I'm afraid we will need to listen to updates as well.

That said, it should be a pretty lightweight task because the methods will only rerun in case of a version change. Upon receiving the event we will compare the current version in the IDL object with the initial one that was passed as a parameter to this class. All the information is in memory so should be ok.

That also said, I will ask around to see if others have a better idea of how to detect database re-connections.

Ok, if we don't have any other option, that's fine. It should be pretty lightweight but at scale we'll be processing a lot of events in case the OVN VIP is moved, or services are updated, etc. Not a critical matter btu if we can do something to optimize it, that'd be great. Is this needed? It looks like there is only one maintenance thread, so only one connection that would be listening for this event? You've been staring at this longer than I have, so I'm probably missing something, but I'd like to understand it better. :)

Is this needed? It looks like there is only one maintenance thread, so only one connection that would be listening for this event? You've been staring at this longer than I have, so I'm probably missing something, but I'd like to understand it better. :)

Ops, I think u r right here... I first thought about this synchronization because of the periodic nature of the maintenance task (every 5 minutes) and this new way of running some maintenance tasks but it's not needed, these migration tasks (the ones returning NeverAgain()) won't run periodically.

And yeah, as you pointed out as well we only have 1 maintenance worker running. Good catch man, I will remove this.

Ok, so I wrote a little test script https://paste.centos.org/view/0caebff0 that just looks at CREATE/UPDATE Connection events. When just restarting the ovsdb-server it seemed like I always got an UPDATE is_connected False->True event. But if I  try doing ovs-appctl --target /usr/local/var/run/openvswitch/ovnnb_db.ctl ovsdb-server/reconnect, it looks like about 50% of the time, I don't get the UPDATE.

So it at least looks possible for there to be a race condition on getting the UPDATE, depending on when in the process the client connects. We will *always* get a CREATE event when reconnecting because we get a db dump upon connection, so looks like it is safer to use that.

Wow thanks a lot for this amazing review Terry!

It all gets a little confusing. One of these days we should rework some of the get_connection() stuff. :p

Exactly, had to add this because the binding_events=False but, I can't just pass binding_events=True because that would instantiate an IDL with the distributed locking mechanism and we do not want/need that for the maintenance task.

Regarding the set_lock(), yeah, perhaps that could be moved to here I believe. I think that should be OK, but, should I move it as part of this patch ? Sounds a bit out of scope idk.

And man, yes, let's refactor this get_connection() at some point... Everything I have to look at the code to and remember again what it's doing there, so confusing...

manifests/profile/base/keystone.pp.message: I'm afraid that I reffered the wrong infomation and it seems this should be "oslo_cache.memcache_pool" instead, according to the comment in keystone.conf

I didn't notice this when I created this patch, but I seems that keystone has its own caching implementation which is affected by oslo.cache configuration.

 https://github.com/openstack/keystone/blob/master/keystone/common/cache/core.py#L116-L134

So the problem is that setting enabled=false explicitly also disabled caching in keystone, which causes performance degradation.

AFAIK, 'dogpile.cache.null' (default) backend effectively disables caching. So when you change the 'cache_backend' to something other than that, you've to change 'enabled' flag to false to disable caching.

So, not sure if this patch has resulted in any change of behavior, unless 'enabled' flag changes local request caching in some way.

Performance improvements seen by changing the flag (to true) with memcache_pool backend is expected, but we should change it in specific jobs rather than change the default here.

why minus one?

Because otherwise we would need to update the priority of the other chassis.

The way the HA Chassis Group work is by electing the chassis with the highest priority. So say we have 3 chassis in the group already with the following priorities: 100, 99, 98.

This code finds the lowest one, which is 98 in our example, and then add the new chassis as 97.
